about.formula_en:
The PANSS Score is calculated by the addition of the selected points:

Variable Points
Positive Scale
Delusions Beliefs which are unfounded, unrealistic, and idiosyncratic Absent 1
Minimal 2
Mild 3
Moderate 4
Moderate-severe 5
Severe 6
Extreme 7
Conceptual disorganization Disorganized process of thinking characterized by disruption of goal-directed sequencing Absent 1
Minimal 2
Mild 3
Moderate 4
Moderate-severe 5
Severe 6
Extreme 7
Hallucinatory behavior Verbal report or behavior indicating perceptions which are not generated by external stimuli Absent 1
Minimal 2
Mild 3
Moderate 4
Moderate-severe 5
Severe 6
Extreme 7
Excitement Hyperactivity as reflected in accelerated motor behavior, heightened responsivity to stimuli, hypervigilance, or excessive mood lability Absent 1
Minimal 2
Mild 3
Moderate 4
Moderate-severe 5
Severe 6
Extreme 7
Grandiosity Exaggerated self-opinion and unrealistic convictions of superiority, including delusions of extraordinary abilities, wealth, knowledge, fame, power, and moral righteousness Absent 1
Minimal 2
Mild 3
Moderate 4
Moderate-severe 5
Severe 6
Extreme 7
Suspiciousness Unrealistic or exaggerated ideas of persecution, as reflected in guardedness, distrustful attitude, suspicious hypervigilance, or frank delusions that others mean harm Absent 1
Minimal 2
Mild 3
Moderate 4
Moderate-severe 5
Severe 6
Extreme 7
Hostility Verbal and nonverbal expressions of anger and resentment, including sarcasm, passive-aggressive behavior, verbal abuse, and assaultiveness Absent 1
Minimal 2
Mild 3
Moderate 4
Moderate-severe 5
Severe 6
Extreme 7
Negative Scale
Blunted affect Diminished emotional responsiveness as characterized by a reduction in facial expression, modulation of feelings, and communicative gestures Absent 1
Minimal 2
Mild 3
Moderate 4
Moderate-severe 5
Severe 6
Extreme 7
Emotional withdrawal Lack of interest in, involvement with, and affective commitment to life’s events Absent 1
Minimal 2
Mild 3
Moderate 4
Moderate-severe 5
Severe 6
Extreme 7
Poor rapport Lack of interpersonal empathy, openness in conversation, and sense of closeness, interest, or involvement with the interviewer Absent 1
Minimal 2
Mild 3
Moderate 4
Moderate-severe 5
Severe 6
Extreme 7
Passive-apathetic social withdrawal Diminished interest and initiative in social interactions due to passivity, apathy, anergy, or avolition Absent 1
Minimal 2
Mild 3
Moderate 4
Moderate-severe 5
Severe 6
Extreme 7
Difficulty in abstract thinking Impairment in the use of the abstract-symbolic mode of thinking, as evidenced by difficulty in classification, forming generalizations, and proceeding beyond concrete or egocentric thinking in problem-solving tasks Absent 1
Minimal 2
Mild 3
Moderate 4
Moderate-severe 5
Severe 6
Extreme 7
Lack of spontaneity and flow of conversation Reduction in the normal flow of communication associated with apathy, avolition, defensiveness, or cognitive deficit Absent 1
Minimal 2
Mild 3
Moderate 4
Moderate-severe 5
Severe 6
Extreme 7
Stereotyped thinking Decreased fluidity, spontaneity, and flexibility of thinking, as evidenced in rigid, repetitious, or barren thought content Absent 1
Minimal 2
Mild 3
Moderate 4
Moderate-severe 5
Severe 6
Extreme 7
General Psychopathology Scale
Somatic concern Physical complaints or beliefs about bodily illness or malfunctions Absent 1
Minimal 2
Mild 3
Moderate 4
Moderate-severe 5
Severe 6
Extreme 7
Anxiety Subjective experience of nervousness, worry, apprehension, or restlessness, ranging from excessive concern to feelings of panic about the present or future Absent 1
Minimal 2
Mild 3
Moderate 4
Moderate-severe 5
Severe 6
Extreme 7
Guilt feelings Sense of remorse or self-blame for real or imagined misdeeds in the past Absent 1
Minimal 2
Mild 3
Moderate 4
Moderate-severe 5
Severe 6
Extreme 7
Tension Overt physical manifestations of fear, anxiety, and agitation, such as stiffness, tremor, profuse sweating, and restlessness Absent 1
Minimal 2
Mild 3
Moderate 4
Moderate-severe 5
Severe 6
Extreme 7
Mannerisms and posturing Unnatural movements or posture as characterized be an awkward, stilted, disorganized, or bizarre appearance Absent 1
Minimal 2
Mild 3
Moderate 4
Moderate-severe 5
Severe 6
Extreme 7
Depression Feelings of sadness, discouragement, helplessness, and pessimism Absent 1
Minimal 2
Mild 3
Moderate 4
Moderate-severe 5
Severe 6
Extreme 7
Motor retardation Reduction in motor activity as reflected in slowing or lessening of movements and speech, diminished responsiveness of stimuli, and reduced body tone Absent 1
Minimal 2
Mild 3
Moderate 4
Moderate-severe 5
Severe 6
Extreme 7
Uncooperativeness Active refusal to comply with the will of significant others, including the interviewer, hospital staff or family, which may be associated with distrust, defensiveness, stubbornness, negativism, rejection of authority, hostility, or belligerence Absent 1
Minimal 2
Mild 3
Moderate 4
Moderate-severe 5
Severe 6
Extreme 7
Unusual thought content Thinking characterized by strange, fantastic, or bizarre ideas, ranging from those which are remote or atypical to those which are distorted, illogical, and patently absurd Absent 1
Minimal 2
Mild 3
Moderate 4
Moderate-severe 5
Severe 6
Extreme 7
Disorientation Lack of awareness of one’s relationship to the milieu, including persons, place, and time, which may be due to confusion or withdrawal Absent 1
Minimal 2
Mild 3
Moderate 4
Moderate-severe 5
Severe 6
Extreme 7
Poor attention Failure in focused alertness manifested by poor concentration, distractibility from internal and external stimuli, and difficulty in harnessing, sustaining, or shifting focus to new stimuli Absent 1
Minimal 2
Mild 3
Moderate 4
Moderate-severe 5
Severe 6
Extreme 7
Lack of judgment and insight Impaired awareness or understanding of one’s own psychiatric condition and life situation Absent 1
Minimal 2
Mild 3
Moderate 4
Moderate-severe 5
Severe 6
Extreme 7
Disturbance of volition Disturbance in the wilful initiation, sustenance, and control of one’s thoughts, behavior, movements, and speech Absent 1
Minimal 2
Mild 3
Moderate 4
Moderate-severe 5
Severe 6
Extreme 7
Poor impulse control Disordered regulation and control of action on inner urges, resulting in sudden, unmodulated, arbitrary, or misdirected discharge of tension and emotions without concern about consequences Absent 1
Minimal 2
Mild 3
Moderate 4
Moderate-severe 5
Severe 6
Extreme 7
Preoccupation Absorption with internally generated thoughts and feelings and with autistic experiences to the detriment of reality orientation and adaptive behavior Absent 1
Minimal 2
Mild 3
Moderate 4
Moderate-severe 5
Severe 6
Extreme 7
Active social avoidance Diminished social involvement associated with unwarranted fear, hostility, or distrust Absent 1
Minimal 2
Mild 3
Moderate 4
Moderate-severe 5
Severe 6
Extreme 7
about.more_info_en:
Interpretation:

PANSS Score Schizophrenia Severity
≤57 Not ill
58-74 Mildly ill
75-94 Moderately ill
95-115 Markedly ill
≥116 Severely ill

Original/Primary Reference.text: Kay SR, Fiszbein A, Opler LA. The positive and negative syndrome scale (Panss) for schizophrenia. Schizophrenia Bulletin. 1987;13(2):261-276.

Other References.text: Leucht S, Kane JM, Kissling W, Hamann J, Etschel E, Engel RR. What does the PANSS mean? Schizophr Res. 2005;79(2-3):231-238.

Validation.text: Levine SZ, Rabinowitz J, Engel R, Etschel E, Leucht S. Extrapolation between measures of symptom severity and change: an examination of the PANSS and CGI. Schizophr Res. 2008;98(1-3):318-322.

how_to_use.use_case_en: Do you use the Positive and Negative Syndrome Scale (PANSS) for Schizophrenia and want to contribute your expertise? Join our contributor team!

next_steps.advice_en: Do you use the Positive and Negative Syndrome Scale (PANSS) for Schizophrenia and want to contribute your expertise? Join our contributor team!

calc.full_title_en: Positive and Negative Syndrome Scale (PANSS) for Schizophrenia

calc.medium_description_en: Measures the prevalence of positive and negative syndromes in schizophrenia.
search_abbreviation_en: Positive and Negative Syndrome Scale (PANSS) for Schizophrenia

seo.keywords_en: Positive and Negative Syndrome Scale (PANSS) for Schizophrenia, panss, panss scale, positive and negative scale, schizophrenia, schizophrenia scale, schizophrenia syndrome scale, positive schizophrenia scale, negative schizophrenia scale, positive syndrome scale, negative syndrome scale
seo.meta_description_en: The Positive and Negative Syndrome Scale (PANSS) for Schizophrenia measures the prevalence of positive and negative syndromes in schizophrenia.

creators.about_en: Stanley R. Kay, PhD, (d. 1990) was a research psychologist at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in the Bronx, New York. He was chief of the schizophrenia research program in the Department of Psychiatry at the medical school and director of physiological research at the Bronx Psychiatric Center. Dr. Kay’s primary research focused on schizophrenia with special emphasis on phenomenological and therapeutic studies.
creators.name: Dr. Stanley R. Kay

cme_faq.answer: MDCalc’s Continuing Medical Education (CME) service allows users to easily earn AMA PRA Category 1 CreditsTM through regular use of MDCalc. Simply put, on top of getting the best medical calculators in the world, your usage will help you achieve your annual CME requirements, including specialty CME, without any extra effort.
cme_faq.question: What is MDCalc CME?

cme_faq.answer: Yes, in support of improving patient care, this activity has been planned and implemented by the Postgraduate Institute for Medicine and MDCalc Ltd. Inc. Postgraduate Institute for Medicine is jointly accredited by the Accreditation Council for Continuing Medical Education (ACCME), the Accreditation Council for Pharmacy Education (ACPE), and the American Nurses Credentialing Center (ANCC), to provide continuing education for the healthcare team.
cme_faq.question: Is MDCalc CME accredited?

cme_faq.answer: Only United States attending physicians, nurse practitioners, nurses, and physician assistants are eligible for our CME service.
cme_faq.question: Who can enroll and how?

cme_faq.answer: We have over 275 CME-eligible calculators across various specialties. You can read the clinical content supporting any CME calculators to start earning. Once you have viewed all the supporting content for a calculator, you will have officially earned the credit amount (0.5 credits) and will be able to redeem a certificate. For now, only calc content in CME-eligible calcs is eligible for CME credits, however, we’ll be expanding our CME service to include more of our content in the future.
cme_faq.question: What activities can I do to earn CME credits?

cme_faq.answer: Simply use our search bar or visit our homepage to easily find CME-eligible calcs. You must be enrolled in our CME service to see which calcs are CME-eligible.
cme_faq.question: Where can I find calcs with which I can earn credits?

cme_faq.answer: Once you’ve enrolled in our CME service, you will have a personal CME Dashboard where you can view all of your earned credits. You can navigate to the dashboard by clicking the CME button in the header at the top of any page.
cme_faq.question: Where can I see which credits Ive earned?

cme_faq.answer: Go to your CME Dashboard and select the credits you’d like to redeem, fill out a few dropdown answers about how you used the calc, and then proceed to checkout.
cme_faq.question: How do I redeem CME credits?

cme_faq.answer: No. Earning credits as you use calcs is free, but either you (or your employer) will need to purchase an annual subscription to redeem your CME certificates.
cme_faq.question: Are CME credits free?

cme_faq.answer: Just like with earned credits, you can view your CME certificates on your CME Dashboard in the “CME Certificates” tab. Certificates include a list of all of the calcs for which CME was earned along with a tally of the specialty CME.
cme_faq.question: Where can I see my CME certificates?

cme_faq.answer: One year from the date of purchase.
cme_faq.question: How long do credits in an annual subscription last?

cme_faq.answer: General; Addiction and Controlled Substances; Cardiac Care; Domestic and Intimate Partner Violence; Geriatrics; HIV and Infectious Disease; Hospice, End-of-Life, Terminal Illness, and Palliative Care; Mental and Behavioral Health; Pain Management; Pediatrics; Stroke; and Trauma.
cme_faq.question: What specialty CME credits are included in the plan?

cme_faq.answer:
Your gift card will be sent via email within 1-2 business days of making your purchase. You will be able to select from the following options - Visa, Amazon.com, Apple. Be sure to claim your gift card offer within 90 days of receiving the email.

Your CME purchase may have implications for tax reporting purposes. The cost of your CME product may or may not be tax-deductible when used for professional purposes. Any reimbursed amount for incentives must be declared as personal income for tax purposes. Please consult your tax advisor. MDCalc does not provide tax advice.
cme_faq.question: I ordered a CME package with a gift card. How does it work?

cme_faq.answer: Per the new guidelines from ACCME, the receipt will separate the cost you paid into the cost of the gift card and the cost of the CME learning activity.
cme_faq.question: What will show on my receipt for CME when it includes a gift card?

cme_faq.answer: You can get a refund (minus any promotional gift amount) within 30-days if the ease of earning and redeeming does not meet your expectations and if you have redeemed no more than 4 credits. Please email team@mdcalc.com to request a refund.
cme_faq.question: How do I get a refund if I'm not satisfied?

cme_faq.answer: You can upgrade your subscription throughout your billing cycle and pay the difference for a higher plan. You may request to downgrade your plan to a lower level to coincide with your next renewal. Please email team@mdcalc.com to request changes.
cme_faq.question: How do I later upgrade to a different plan if I need more credits?

cme_faq.answer: Gift card plans are available for 1 year and do not auto-renew. Standard, non gift-card subscriptions are auto-renewed annually. You can disable the automatic renewal of your subscription at any time by emailing team@mdcalc.com.
cme_faq.question: Do CME plans auto-renew?

cme_faq.answer: If you’re part of a team or practice that wants to sign up five or more physicians, please email us at team@mdcalc.com for more information.
cme_faq.question: How do I get information on a discounted bulk subscription program for my institution, team, or practice?

cme_faq.answer: On July 28, 2022, ACCME updated the guidelines regarding the use of high-value incentives. These guidelines allow for the use of gift card rewards in a regulated manner. Visit the ACCME website to read their guidelines.
cme_faq.question: Did the ACCME decide to regulate gift cards?
